content:
Ruth Nicholls said
Is it possible to copy just the Mail folder from a Thunderbird Profile backup in Time Machine on Mac?

No it is not. The folders of mail are associated with account numbers in your preferences so a plain copy it not the answer. Generally Time Machine is not the answer.

I have deleted an email account from Thunderbird and I did not tick Delete Data so the emails are still there in my Profile but they no longer show up in the tree in Thunderbird on my Mac ( OS 14.8 Sonoma). I had a lot of subfolders into which I had put incoming and sent emails on particular topics. For example I had a folder called Family, and inside that I had a subfolder called Birthdays as well as many other family related topics. My last Time Machine back up is about a month ago but that would be good enough to restore from. I tried ‘Import’ in Thunderbird but it only imported the main folders and the emails within but not the subfolders. I have another email address besides the deleted one and if I overwrite the whole Profile with the older one from Time Machine it will lose a lot of new stuff accumulated since that backup. Any help most appreciated

Can you just add the add the account back into Thunderbird? Once you have an account you can point the account to the correct folder which you say explicitly that you did not opt to delete when you removed the account. Problem solved without extra tools or trying to merge data that has not been removed back in somehow. The can be done in account settings > Server settings by changing the account directory to the correct one.

I assume you have now realized that all of an account data hangs off the account so removing it removes the agility to access the data for the account. As you point out it does not remove the data, just you ability to access it. Sometimes I wish these folder trees still had the joining lines on them so folk would realize that the stuff is connected and where.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Thanks Matt. Unfortunately I can't add the account back as there was a specific reason to remove it. There must be some way to get the emails back. Maybe I will have to use the whole Profile from the last Time Machine backup. The old stuff is more important to me than the latest.
creator: ruthnichollsphotos

content:
Ruth Nicholls said
There must be some way to get the emails back.

Open your Thunderbird profile folder, then quit the Thunderbird application. In the profile folder open the folder Mail, identify and open the "pop.xxx.yy" account folder which should still contain the messages of your deleted POP account. Copy the mailbox files (without suffixe) such as Inbox, Sent, Drafts, Archives ... to Local Folders which are also located in the Mail folder. If you see file folders such as Inbox.sbd, Archives.sbd, ... also copy them to Local Folders. You may have created personal folders in the old POP account such as Business, Vacations, Family, ... Copy them to Local Folders, too. Don't bother about the .msf files. When you restart TB you should see folders and messages of your deleted account in Local Folders in the folder pane.

Ruth Nicholls said
Maybe I will have to use the whole Profile from the last Time Machine backup. The old stuff is more important to me than the latest.

If you use your profile in the Time Machine backup from one month ago with the still existing POP account you will also import the "specific reason" for which you have already deleted it once! Then it would be easier to follow Matt's proposal to add the account back in Thunderbird and point it to the corresponding old account folder in Mail.

content:
Kami Scott said
My previous computer crashed and got a new one (Win 11 of course - new for me). I downloaded Thunderbird. With the help of an Earthlink (my email) tech, all but one of my emails (gmail) were entered. Then I downloaded and began reading them. The first thing I noticed was the Next and Previous buttons are missing (or placed where I don't see them). The second thing I noticed is that when I click on one email to read, all the emails in the respective Inbox also open. This is very annoying. I also hope someone can tell me the info I need to add a gmail account. (I rarely use it, but there two websites which require a gmail email to log on.) And I had made a T-bird "backup" but haven't used it yet. I'd like to IF I can locate it. P.S. Is it possible to shut off the AI "help" while writing this. I find it annoying, slows me down.

1. R. click the Toobar > Customize > drag the Next and Previous buttons up to the toolbar.

2. Second thing: I haven't heard of that ever happening. Does it also happen in Troubleshoot mode?

3. New Gmail account - see https://support.google.com/mail/answer/56256?hl=en. If you want to use TB to access Gmail, see https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-gmail/.

4. AI - probably not.
creator: siffemoz

content: Unfortunately, nobody here will be able to help you with that. Did you get a message back that the message couldn't be delivered? Do you have a copy of the message in your Sent folder?
creator: siffemoz

content:
Potrebbero essere recuperabili se sul cestino non è stata fatta la compattazione (manuale o automatica). Devi recuperare dal profilo un file chiamato trash (senza estensione) e poi aprirlo con un programma per gestire il formato MBOX, ad esempio questo ->https://www.mitec.cz/mailview.html

Per individuare il file trash individua la cartella del profilo di Thunderbird -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/kb/profili-thunderbird poi cerca il file nelle sottocartelle mail e imapmail nella cartella relativa all'account da cui hai cancellato le mail.
creator: @next

content: Try R. click Inbox > Properties > click 'Repair folder' button, then R. click Inbox > Compact.
creator: siffemoz

content: Fantastic! Success. Thank you for your help. DD

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content: I don't think you're doing anything wrong. I think you figured out how Thunderbird works.
creator: mozilla98

content:
Taking the right actions to ensure that all your messages are in Thunderbird (e.g., set for off-line use) may be sufficient (I don't know), but then Thunderbird would keep trying to connect to that account after it was deleted, so you would want to move the messages to local folders later anyway.

The best thing to do is to to copy all the server folders to your local folders account. You can even select the folders and copy them all in one step to the local folders account. Very easy.

Back up your profile first.

You'll have to decide when to do that and how to monitor for new messages that must be copied to local folders too. Or you could create a message filter that moves all new messages to a local folder so you don't have to monitor.

When you're done, back up your profile again.

I know IMAP pretty well. I don't know much about gmail. One thing to consider with gmail is the allmail folder. You'll want to make sure that you have a good understanding of what is in it before doing anything with it.
creator: mozilla98

creator: davidsk

content:
Did you turn off the filter in account settings > junk settings?

I have seen no reports of turning off the junk filter not working. So the junk mail that you are seeing is probably being filtered by the server, not by Thunderbird.

Do you have any message filters?

Some people get frustrated with Thunderbird's filter because they do not know how it works and how to train it. In case you have not seen this: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/thunderbird-and-junk-spam-messages

creator: mozilla98

content:
Rick,

We never had any problems until Thunderbird introduced the junk filter. We have had problems ever since. I just disabled the junk filter two days ago and then the global one one day ago.

I believe you are saying that it is sheer coincidence that we started having server problems with our junk mail at exactly the same time as Thunderbird introduced its filter a couple years ago.

I know this highly improbable coincidence is a possibility, but I am dubious.

I am not trying to be mean or snarky, but we just do not need any filter. I am fairly computer literate, but changes to the server are totally beyond me.
creator: EastTenn

content:
I do not know if there is a bug in the enabled/disabled status. All I know is that I have not seen reports on this forum that suggest that there is.

I am not saying that it is sheer coincidence that you started having problems when you started using Thunderbird's filter. I am saying that any messages going to junk after you turn off Thunderbird's filter are probably there because your e-mail service provider is putting them there.

You don't have to make any changes to the server, just know that your e-mail service provider is probably putting messages into your junk folder. Your may have options in webmail for how aggressive that filter is.
creator: mozilla98

content: Rick's concern can be easily tested. Shut down thunderbird, and log onto your email provider's site and see if mail goes to junk.

content: If the folders are within the IMAP account, and not local to the PC, your Fairemail app should see them fine. Any app running IMAP should have no problem. I use Bluemail and it interacts well with PC thunderbird because both are interacting with the same IMAP account. Check to be sure your phone is set for IMAP, and whether there are settings in Fairemail to modify.
